Being predictable does not mean time has failed to mark your past and future as past and future.  It just means that your movements are repeating themselves.  You are describing recursive motion, not a lack of cause and effect.  The Earth does one thing, without fail, all the time, provided nothing acts upon it: It orbits the sun while in rotation.  We have calendars to mark the days (and leap years to handle the remainder of time accrued each year).  Does the Earth have a lack of cause and effect, or does it just repeat itself because conditions in the universe see fit that it should fit the pattern?  The answer is the latter.  All things have causes and all things have effects, even if the effect appears to be to do nothing or the cause is not apparent or not important.  And the patterns?  The pattern of measuring things by number was caused by people who wanted to break down what they see and hear and touch into logical constructs of knowledge that can be passed along instead of having to re-measure everything repeatedly.  To wit, a progression of learning.  We are not in the Dark Ages because we have something which caused us to have fundamental facts built up and edited over time to draw upon.  Does it matter on the molecular level that we understand math?  Do particles care?  Maybe not.  Does that mean they lack progression, a series of events that move forwards in reality?  Hell no.

In Philosophy causes can exist without the element of time. Meaning that causes can be atemporal (indifferent to time) for e.g. the indentation in a pillow caused by a ball placed on it doesn't necessarily follow it chronologically but rather it occurs at the same time as the ball is placed on it yet we can safely label the placing of the ball as the cause to the effect (the indentation in the pillow). Consider this definition of cause " something that produces an effect" there is no time in this definition, also consider this proposition  "every effect has a cause " this proposition is actually an axiom, arguing against it is tantamount to saying that something can come from nothing. Obviously this is an untenable position to take.

All that can be stated is that the cause of these quantum events is unknown within the framework of the universe in which we live. It can not be said that there is absolutely no cause at all. Therefore, decisive evidence is still required in order to prove that there is no cause for quantum events, and this evidence is absent as long as there is no certainty that all existence is no more than our universe we live in. In fact, today, we have many theories of multiple universes with the possibility that they affect one another.

But in all actuality, we can't say the patterns exist either, because we can't observe everything single instance to know if the pattern actually is absolute. We can't observe the laws of physics, we can only observe their effects. While it's not based around a sequence of time, we are still postulating a cause and an effect relationship by saying these patterns cause the observations.

I think you just spat on relativity. Any event which lies on the past light cone of another can have a causal relationship with the latter.
If you are dealing with, for instance, a fluid, then the characteristic velocity is the speed of sound in that fluid, (you could think of it as a "sound cone") and any event within the past "sound cone" of the fluid can have a causal relationship with the event in question. You can associate a characteristic speed to any phenomenon and then you have a definition of causality:

"Any phenomenon that occurs in the past within the distance required for a signal traveling at the characteristic speed (of the signal produced by the phenomenon) to reach an event has a causal relationship with said event"

(Note: here, event is used in the sense of a point in spacetime with some arbitrary coordinates (t,x,y,z))

You barely mention it here, but I feel like you gave the root cause for the notion of "cause" and "effect" in your previous video: the initial conditions of the universe. We started out with a low-entropy universe some time in the past, and we're still riding the causal wave flowing forward from that time.

Also, I find the notion that removing a patch of molecules from an explosion wouldn't significantly change the reverse of the explosion to be HIGHLY suspect... events like the reverse of an explosion, the union of a bunch of gas particles back into explosive substrate, are INCREDIBLY unlikely. The only reason explosions occur in time at all is because the initial conditions of the universe were very low-entropy, ie. VERY unlikely to evolve from a random universe, and that unlikelihood has gotten less and less over time but is still making its influence felt in the present. (AND because gravity can do things that locally reduce entropy, if you ignore heat dissapation, such as bringing particles together and sorting them by mass/structure)

To say that there are patterns is to admit there is cause and effect because it is from the relationship of cause and effect that the pattern "arises" so to speak. To say that classical mechanics of isolated parts doesn't distinguish past from future doesn't negate cause and effect but acknowledges their intimate relationship. It's precisely because of the nature of cause and effect that we can describe it so symmetrically.
Further, this is a very narrow, modern view of cause and effect that is being claimed to be overturned (or at best being claimed to apply only to entropic macroscopic systems). Most forms of cause and effect don't even need to appeal to time at all. On a hypothetical beach in a completely eternal, static universe there is a boot. The boot has always been there and always will be and no grain of sand has ever moved or ever will move. The boot print in the sand had no temporal beginning but we can still say that it was caused by the weight of the boot pressed into the sand.
Other examples: If every atom in my body was replaced with silicon I would cease to be a living human being. What I'm made of is a cause to the effect of me being human and alive. This cause/effect relationship doesn't appeal to time. Similarly, if you isolated all the material elements that make me and separated them into piles, yes, you would have all the material that makes a living human being but you still wouldn't have a living human being. The material needs to be arranged in a certain way to be a human being. This arrangement is a cause that doesn't depend on time. In order to be a living human being this arrangement of material needs to be engaged and interacting which is the only cause that requires time (and as we saw with the boot print above not all interaction type causes need to be temporal either).
To be a cause all one has to be is a feature that, if missing or altered in some way, would alter whatever it is you're observing. A feature can be a physical object, an activity, an interaction, a motion, a relationship, etc. To be an effect all you have to be is contingent, dependent, on some feature. From this relationship regularities and patterns will arise (like, for example, what we call the laws of physics). That the relationship is time symmetrical or even completely atemporal in no way proves the relationship doesn't exist or is meaningless.

The particles of the universe knows nothing of our laws of GR, QM, 2LoT, and all other human inventions, including the concept of cause/effect and time. All they do is try to live from moment to moment.

0:36 The missile knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is (whichever is greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation. The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the missile from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is. Consequently, the position where it is, is now the position that it wasn't, and it follows that the position that it was, is now the position that it isn't.
In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't, the system has acquired a variation, the variation being the difference between where the missile is, and where it wasn't. If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA. However, the missile must also know where it was.

The missile guidance computer scenario works as follows. Because a variation has modified some of the information the missile has obtained, it is not sure just where it is. However, it is sure where it isn't, within reason, and it knows where it was. It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't, or vice-versa, and by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of where it shouldn't be, and where it was, it is able to obtain the deviation and its variation, which is called error.

But if you mess up even slightly, it will all go haywire. It will no longer be in exactly the right pattern for a ball of hot water to turn into hydrogen, oxygen and a spark. Entropy will continue increasing instead of decreasing.

And if you look at all that backwards, that means that if you change a tiny detail in the present, then the past will have entropy reverse. For all intents and purposes, you'll have two different futures leading from that moment. The normal one, and one where everything suddenly switched directions but entropy nonetheless continued to increase.

I think you missed something important. When you're talking about records, there will usually be multiple records, and they will all be correlated with one another, so that they agree on whether or not the recorded event happened. If one of the records happened to not exist, there would be plenty others. That makes each one a potential record.

That's not the same with causes. If records are the time-reversed versions of causes, then many records correlated with one another would be the time-reversed versions of many potential causes being correlated with one another. To make it a time-reversed version, each potential cause would need to be unneeded, redundant, so that if one of the causes happened to not exist, there would be plenty others, and the event would happen.

But the real difference, I think, comes from the correlation. For potential records, they will be correlated. For potential causes though, it's incredibly unlikely that they will all be correlated, IOW, that all of the matches will either light or not light, but not half-and-half. (unlikely unless ...) And that brings it back to entropy, how it's incredibly unlikely that all of the records would be correlated unless they all came from the same low-entropy state, the event. (unlikely unless ... those matches were records of some other even lower-entropy state)

(For example the birth of your mother caused your birth).

Kant was the fist to argue that cause and effect do not exist. They're just constructs created by our minds to make sense of the universe.

So basically this video uses the many worlds interpretation in a tacit manner, because it just says that our whole understanding of time is intrinsically part of the problem, as we DO NOT have any way of computing how many universes can lead to our current "state function". I think I get it, and it is consistent.

But we are not certain about the reality of many-worlds, which to me imply at least one hypothesis that HAVE to be made, namely that time is a parameter in a nonquantum gravitational setting (which is basically our currently understood quantum mechanics). This has as consequence the notion that there is no fundamental aspect to the arrow of time as an observation, which means that it is just a manifestation of the second law of thermodynamics.

While it really seems like a reasonable bunch of hypothesis, and definitely worth betting some money on, I don't think we really are sure about the nature of time, in the sense that we don't really know all too well how it works.

Time might be something weirder, as the Wooters-Page equation suggests.

Guess we'll have to find out through experiment which is the case, because (while a very elegant solution) we can't be sure until we touch such wound.

I think he is ignoring the fact that the time and perspective
at/from which he chooses to observe these scenarios is skewing his results.
The carbon in the pencil is an effect caused by the atomic bombs.
The fact that your viewing that from the time/perspective of the pencil doesn't change that.
Cause and effect can't go backwards in time because the definition we gave those words
are intertwined with our concept of time in the first place. Records/Memories ARE effects.

Further (if you care to read), about the position and momentum of the particles ( 0:35 ),
The present position at which you are observing that particle is both the effect of it's previous
position, and the cause of future position. Applying the concept of cause and effect
to a chained sequence of events becomes broken logic when you negate the fact
that a single event can be both the cause of a prior event, and the effect of a following event at the same time.

And for numbers ( 0:49 ) , 42 does cause 43 to be 43. Not the actual name of the number,
but the value we assign to that number is the effect of the number before it. Without 42,
43 would hold the numeric value of 42. That is why infinity works. The idea that any number
can be a catalyst to a larger number. That is cause and effect.

You haven't shown that cause and effect are misnomers, but simply that natural science cannot denote or determine them.
Of course the cause of an explosion isn't a spark; the cause of the spark is just exactly the same as the cause of the explosion.
I'm disappointed with this pervasive philosophy that natural science fully explains and provides the ultimate explanation for the natural world, when it can only ever describe what happens and how, but never why.

I wish more people would learn about and fall in love with science as much as the next nerd, but because they won't find answers about cause and effect therein, I'd be much happier if MinutePhysics presented the videos as describing how causality works in nature, rather than pretending (inadvertently, I'm sure) to offer conclusions about the nature of causality.

I don't think it's accurate to suggest that a "cause" is the same as a "record", unless you want to suggest a completely static timeline, devoid of free will, where nothing is the result of anything except predetermination. In the example of the pencil, even if time moved backward, the pencil would show evidence of nuclear testing, but the testing wouldn't be the direct result of the pencil. The radioactive elements in the pencil are, however, the direct result of nuclear testing. This would be especially evident in instances where multiple potential causes could have just one effect, like a watermelon being destroyed sufficiently so that the specific "cause" can't be determined by the "effect".
